conbody.p: NCC CNF is deployed in the network as one pair of Service Managers (SM) and one or more pairs of Managed Elements (MEs). A pair of MEs are active/active from the network perspective, with one-half of their subscribers being active on one ME and secondary on the other ME, and the other half of the subscribers being reversed. NCC CNF pairs are deployed in two geographically diverse sites. In addition to SM and ME being separate, NCC CNF can also be deployed with IG.
For more information about field deployments of NCC CNF, see CNF Installation and Update Guide in the NCC documentation set.

section.title: ME deployment models
section.p: The following are variations of ME deployment models.

li.p: Independent ME pairs In this model, each ME pair is independent from the other pairs. Received traffic is either processed locally or site-routed to the other ME in the pair (or is rejected). There is no NCC site-routing to an ME outside of this pair. The operator's network must perform routing to ensure that a particular message arrives to the correct ME pair, if that is required.

ul.li: Networked ME pairs In this model, all MEs can communicate with each other and know which subscribers are homed on any of the MEs in the network. When a message arrives at an ME, if the subscriber is not homed on this local ME, then this ME can site-route this message to the home ME anywhere in the network, not limited to just the other ME in this pair.

section.title: Integrated SM and ME
section.p: The model when NCC is deployed with separate SM and ME might yield more independent scaling and fault tolerance between the SM and ME functions, but it results in a larger footprint. As another option, NCC CNF can be deployed with the SM microservices integrated into the same Kubernetes cluster/namespace as the ME microservices, which yields a reduced overall footprint due to sharing of common services.
The following are the variations of integrated SM and ME:

li.p: Integrated SM and ME Small deployments with an SM pair and a single ME pair might further optimize the deployment footprint by combining an SM and ME into a single system. While adding SM into an ME requires some extra containers for components such as the SM application, the overall footprint is reduced due to a sharing of some common services such as database, Kafka, BTEL infrastructure, and so on.

ul.li: Integrated SM and ME with additional ME pairs In a future version, network operators will be able to grow additional MEs into their network deployment.
